description.en: The Ferdowsi Millennial Celebration commemorates the 1000th anniversary celebration of the great Persian poet Ferdowsi and his epic masterpiece, the Shahnameh. This historic event, held in 1934, brought together scholars, poets, and dignitaries from around the world to honor Ferdowsi's extraordinary contribution to Persian literature, culture, and language. The celebration underscored the enduring significance of the Shahnameh as one of the world's greatest epic poems and its role in preserving Persian identity and heritage.

description.en: The main ceremonies of the 2,500-year Celebration of the Persian Empire began on this day in 1971 (20-26 Mehr 1350). This historic event was held at Persepolis and Pasargadae, bringing together heads of state and dignitaries from around the world to commemorate 2,500 years of continuous Persian monarchy and imperial tradition. The celebration showcased Iran's rich cultural heritage, ancient history, and the continuity of Persian civilization from Cyrus the Great to the modern era. The ceremonies featured elaborate cultural displays, historical reenactments, and diplomatic gatherings, marking one of the most significant cultural and political events in modern Iranian history.

description.en: Ayathrem Gahambar is a Zoroastrian festival celebrating the creation of plants. This ancient six-day festival (typically October 12-16) honors the plant kingdom and is one of the six seasonal festivals (Gahambars) that mark important cosmic events in Zoroastrian cosmology. The Gahambars are times of celebration, prayer, and community gathering, reflecting the deep connection between humanity and the natural world, and the importance of agriculture and plant life in sustaining civilization.

description.en: Cyrus Day at Persepolis commemorates Cyrus the Great, founder of the Achaemenid Empire. This day honors his legacy of justice, tolerance, and human rights as exemplified in the Cyrus Cylinder, one of history's earliest declarations of human rights. Persepolis, the ceremonial capital of the Achaemenid Empire, serves as a powerful symbol of Persian grandeur and the achievements of ancient Iranian civilization. This day celebrates the ideals of freedom, justice, and respect for diverse peoples that Cyrus represented.

description.en: The beginning of Aban month marks the start of the Month of Waters (Abangan), which initiates water-related festivals associated with Anahita, the ancient Persian goddess of waters, fertility, and wisdom. Anahita was one of the most revered deities in ancient Persian religion, symbolizing the life-giving power of water and the sacredness of rivers and springs. This period celebrates the essential role of water in sustaining life and civilization.

description.en: United Nations Day commemorates the anniversary of the UN Charter entering into force in 1945. This day celebrates the achievements and contributions of the United Nations in maintaining international peace and security, promoting human rights, and fostering social and economic development worldwide.

description.en: On this day, Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi, the son of Reza Shah Pahlavi, the king of Iran, was born in Tehran. His reign was a turning point in the country's path to modernization, reform, and expansion of its industrial, educational, and cultural infrastructure. His birthday commemorates one of the most important and transformative periods in Iran's contemporary history.

significance.en: A reminder of the beginning of a new chapter in Iran's contemporary history and a period of modernization and widespread change; a memorial to recognize one of the country's most influential political and cultural figures of the 20th century.

description.en: On this day, the official coronation ceremony of Mohammad Reza Shah Pahlavi was held in Golestan Palace. This magnificent ceremony took place after 26 years of his reign and symbolized the consolidation of power, political stability, and the beginning of a new era of reform and modernization in Iran. The coronation of 1346 can be considered one of the most important symbolic moments in the country's contemporary history.

description.en: Loyalty to Homeland Day is a day dedicated to honoring commitment and devotion to one's country. This day celebrates the deep connection between citizens and their homeland, emphasizing the importance of patriotism, national unity, and dedication to preserving the cultural and historical heritage of the nation.

description.en: This day honors Gordafrid (Gordafarid) and Kaveh the Blacksmith, two legendary heroes from Persian mythology and the Shahnameh. Gordafrid was a brave female warrior who fought valiantly in the Persian epic tradition, representing courage and heroism. Kaveh the Blacksmith is a symbol of resistance against tyranny, who raised his blacksmith's apron as a banner in defiance of the tyrant Zahhak, becoming an enduring symbol of freedom and justice in Persian culture.

description.en: Cyrus the Great Day commemorates the anniversary of Cyrus the Great's entry into Babylon in 539 BCE and the issuance of the Cyrus Cylinder, considered one of history's earliest declarations of human rights. Cyrus the Great, founder of the Achaemenid Empire, established principles of tolerance, justice, and respect for diverse peoples and cultures. The Cyrus Cylinder stands as a testament to his vision of a just and inclusive empire, inspiring concepts of human rights and freedom that resonate across the ages.

description.en: This day commemorates the plight of Iranians who have been taken hostage or forced into exile due to political persecution. It serves as a reminder of the suffering endured by many Iranians who have been separated from their homeland, either through hostage-taking or forced exile, highlighting the ongoing struggle for freedom and the return of all Iranians to their homeland.

description.en: Nowruz, meaning 'new day', is the most important celebration in Iranian culture and marks the beginning of the new year in the Solar Hijri calendar. This ancient festival, with over 3,000 years of history, is observed at the spring equinox (usually March 20 or 21) and symbolizes renewal, hope, and the arrival of spring. Nowruz is celebrated in Iran, Afghanistan, Tajikistan, and Iranian communities worldwide.

description.en: Ferdowsi Day is observed on the 25th of Ordibehesht, commemorating Abolqasem Ferdowsi, the great Iranian poet and creator of the Shahnameh. Ferdowsi preserved the Persian language and culture by composing the Shahnameh and created one of the greatest works of Persian literature. This day honors his contributions to the Persian language and literature.

Khayyam gained worldwide fame with his quatrains and also made great achievements in mathematics and astronomy. This day honors his contributions to literature, mathematics, and astronomy.

description.en:
On 13 June 2009, immediately after the disputed presidential results were announced, the streets of Tehran, Isfahan, Shiraz, and Tabriz were filled with people wearing green wristbands and holding â€œWhere is my vote?â€ placards. Students, artists, and ordinary families marched shoulder to shoulder, breaking the information blockade with cellphone footage.

The demonstrations quickly evolved into nightly sit-ins, human chains, and walls of slogans, reviving the idea of nationwide civil resistance for the first time in yearsâ€”a legacy that later echoed in the Aban 2019 protests and the Woman, Life, Freedom uprising.

description.en:
On 20 June 2009, Neda Agha-Soltan collapsed near Tehranâ€™s Kargar Street after a bullet fired from the direction of security forces pierced her chest. Friends desperately tried to stop the bleeding, but the video of her final breaths traveled the world within minutes and became the defining symbol of the Green Movementâ€™s repression.

While global outrage spread, her family was denied a public funeral and security forces guarded her grave. Each year her name is invoked by grieving mothers and justice-seekers, reminding the world of the price citizens paid for defending their votes.

description.en:
At 4 a.m. on 9 July 1999, special forces in black uniforms stormed the Tehran University dorms, smashing doors, dragging students out of bed, and burning books and personal photos. Reports of beatings and students thrown from windows spread like wildfire, inspiring universities in Tabriz, Mashhad, and Shiraz to rise as well.

For six days, students blocked Tehranâ€™s Amirabad Street with the chant â€œStudents die but never surrender,â€ forging a bond with surrounding neighborhoods. The brutal crackdown served as the first major warning about organized state violence and mapped the road for later waves of civil resistance.

description.en:
On 11 July 2003, Zahra Kazemiâ€”an Iranian-Canadian photojournalistâ€”was detained while photographing families waiting outside Evin Prison. Continuous interrogations turned violent; she suffered a fractured skull, internal bleeding, and was rushed to Baghiatollah Hospital.

A week later officials merely informed her family of her death and blocked any independent autopsy. The case, initially denied, exposed the machinery of torture and forced confessions and became a symbol of media repression and the perils facing independent journalists.

description.en:
On 21 July 2021, residents of Ahvaz, Susangerd, Shadegan, and smaller Khuzestan towns marched in unbearable heat with empty bottles chanting â€œWater is life.â€ Live ammunition and tear gas answered their basic demandâ€”drinkable waterâ€”while images of the mud-clogged Karun River flooded social media.

For more than a week the protests expanded beyond water, voicing demands for self-determination and an end to ethnic discrimination. This environmental uprising proved that resource injustice is inseparable from political dissent and foreshadowed the fury that later ignited the Woman, Life, Freedom movement.

description.en:
On 6 August 1991, agents linked to the Islamic Republic infiltrated Shapour Bakhtiarâ€™s suburban Paris home, disarmed his bodyguard, and stabbed him to death. Bakhtiar, the last prime minister under the Shah and a fierce critic of the new regime, had lived under French police protection for years.

His assassination triggered grief and outrage among dissidents and proved that the regimeâ€™s extraterritorial terror network could reach the heart of Europe. The killing foreshadowed the â€œchain murdersâ€ scandal and fueled demands for protection of exiled activists.

significance.en: Bakhtiar's assassination typified the regime's policy of eliminating dissidents, a pattern repeated in the chain murders and in crackdowns on movements like Woman, Life, Freedom.

description.en:
On 12 September 2020, 27-year-old wrestler Navid Afkari was executed after being arrested during the August 2018 protests and enduring months of torture. In letters smuggled from prison, he described long stretches in solitary confinement and cable beatings used to coerce a fabricated confession.

On execution day his family was denied a final visit; he was granted only a brief call to say goodbye. The hanging sparked a global outcry as athletes and human-rights groups accused the Islamic Republic of extrajudicial killingâ€”a narrative that still beats at the heart of Iranâ€™s protest movements.

description.en:
On 16 September 2022, 22-year-old Kurdish woman Mahsa (Jina) Amini died at Tehranâ€™s Kasra Hospital three days after morality police beat her in a van, leaving her with a swollen skull and bruised body. Eyewitness accounts of batons and the familyâ€™s frantic search fueled public outrage.

Footage from her funeral in Saqqez, where mourners chanted â€œWoman, Life, Freedom,â€ quickly became the common language of nationwide protests. Mahsaâ€™s name now signifies resistance to systemic violence against women and a demand for justice for all victims of state repression.

description.en:
On 17 September 2022, a day after Mahsa Aminiâ€™s burial, women in Saqqez marched unveiled while men formed human shields around them. Flames of protest spread to Tehran, Sanandaj, Mashhad, and even remote towns as â€œWoman, Life, Freedomâ€ echoed down every alley.

The uprising quickly forged networks of student strikes, artist sit-ins, and diaspora solidarity. Generation Z, marginalized youth, and grieving mothers joined forces, proving the struggle is more than politicsâ€”it is a battle to reclaim everyday life from the machinery of oppression.

description.en:
On 23 September 2022, Nika Shakarami vanished after joining demonstrations on Tehranâ€™s Enghelab Street; nine days later her family was handed her bruised, broken body. A budding artist who loved drawing and music, she told her aunt in a brief final call, â€œIâ€™m running,â€ before the line went dead.

Security forces forced the family to bury her quietly in Khorramabad and even disrupted the mourning ceremony. Nikaâ€™s story epitomizes the fate of defiant young women who paid the ultimate price for the dream of freedom.

description.en:
On 24 September 2022, 16-year-old Sarina Esmailzadeh left her playful social-media videos behind and joined protests in Karajâ€™s Gohardasht district. Witnesses reported riot police chasing her across rooftops and beating her to death with batons, while officials falsely claimed she fell.

Her family was forced to bury her under surveillance at Behesht-e Sakineh cemetery, and journalists were blocked from showing the real injuries. Sarinaâ€™s name now stands for the spirited voices of Generation Z, whose humor and daily videos were crushed simply because they protested.

description.en:
7 Mehr commemorates the passing of Kianoosh Sanjari, a Green Movement journalist and blogger who spent years bouncing between prison and exile before dying in the United States from trauma inflicted by torture. He provided firsthand reports on the 2009 protests and the abuses inside Kahrizak detention center, enduring multiple spells in solitary.

His death in exile shows that the cost of pursuing truth is not limited to jail-time; psychological erosion and forced separation from home are part of the toll. Sanjariâ€™s memory bridges the Green Movement and Woman, Life, Freedom, reminding us that storytellers themselves become silent victims of repression.

significance.en: Sanjari's life and death highlight the enduring cost of opposing the Islamic Republic and connect earlier struggles to Woman, Life, Freedom.

description.en:
On 3 November 2012, Sattar Beheshtiâ€”a working-class bloggerâ€”was arrested by Iranâ€™s cyber police for posts about corruption and economic hardship. Four days later his family received his swollen, bruised body, bearing cable marks and handcuff cuts, while officials blamed â€œshock.â€

Cellmates testified that interrogators tortured him with â€œghapaniâ€ shackling and relentless punches and kicks. Sattarâ€™s case became the emblem of systematic torture inside security detention centers, and his mother still pleads for justice with the words â€œGive me back my son.â€

description.en:
On 15 November 2019, after gasoline prices tripled overnight, protests began in Ahvaz and Sirjan and spread to hundreds of towns within hours. Authorities shut down the national internet for three days to conceal the crackdown, yet reports revealed hundreds killed and thousands arrested.

Demonstrators denounced systemic corruption alongside price hikes, and in several cities government buildings became targets of rage. Aban 2019 stands as one of the bloodiest uprisings in modern Iran; families of the slainâ€”such as Pouya Bakhtiariâ€”have since become pillars of the justice-seeking movement.

description.en:
On 27 October 2022, Mahshad Shahidiâ€”a chef and charity volunteer in Arakâ€”was arrested while joining the Woman, Life, Freedom rallies. That same night she died in police custody from heavy blows to her head and face, and her family was forced to bury her quietly.

Friends recalled her as someone who cooked for child laborers and supplied meals to protesters in the days before her death. Mahshadâ€™s killing proved that state violence targets not only prominent activists but every compassionate voice standing with the movement.

description.en:
On 16 November 2022, Kian Pirfalak was in a car with his family heading toward Izehâ€™s central square when security forces opened fire on passing vehicles. Bullets shattered the windshield and killed the nine-year-old in his motherâ€™s arms, injuring his father and brother.

At the funeral, mourners recited Kianâ€™s beloved poem about his wooden boat while his mother declared, â€œThey said he wasnâ€™t shot, but I saw it with my own eyes.â€ His death became the stark symbol of a crackdown that shows no mercy even to children, sparking a new wave of nationwide solidarity.

description.en:
On 22 November 2019, 27-year-old Pouya Bakhtiari was filming protests in Karajâ€™s Mehrshahr when security forces shot him in the head. He had joined the demonstrations with his mother and sister to denounce the fuel price hikes, and his phone captured the final moments.

When the family announced a public memorial for his fortieth day, they were arrested and threatened. His father, Manouchehr Bakhtiari, later became a prominent justice-seeking voice and has been detained repeatedly in attempts to silence the â€œblood avengers of Aban.â€

description.en:
On 12 December 2022, Majidreza Rahnavard was publicly hanged from a crane on Mashhadâ€™s Maâ€™alem Boulevard after a trial that lasted less than 26 days. Accused of fatally stabbing two Basij members, he was denied a lawyer of his choosing and meaningful defense.

Images of the noose around the 23-year-oldâ€™s neckâ€”his wrists still bearing torture marksâ€”shocked society. The rushed execution turned fear into collective anger and exposed the regimeâ€™s reliance on staged killings to crush the Woman, Life, Freedom movement.

description.en:
On 22 November 1998, nationalist-religious leaders Dariush and Parvaneh Forouhar were stabbed dozens of times in their home on Tehranâ€™s Hedayat Street. Agents posing as service workers gained entry and attempted to stage the crime scene after the killings.

The murders ignited the exposure of the Intelligence Ministryâ€™s â€œchain murdersâ€ project, revealing a systematic plan to eliminate dissidents. Despite constant pressure, the Forouhar family holds annual memorials to keep the case alive and demand accountability.

description.en:
On 28 December 2017, a small rally over egg prices in Mashhad escalated within hours as chants turned to â€œDeath to the dictator,â€ and cities like Kermanshah, Qahderijan, Izeh, and Tuyserkan ignited simultaneously. Social media wielded by unknown youth broadcast arrests and shootings, confronting the regime with a decentralized wave for the first time.

In under two weeks more than 70 cities witnessed unrest, banks and governor offices were attacked, and thousands were detained. Dey 2017 proved nationwide anger was not confined to the capital and laid the psychological groundwork for Aban 2019 and the Woman, Life, Freedom uprising.

description.en:
On 8 January 2020, Ukrainian Airlines Flight PS752 was struck by two IRGC surface-to-air missiles barely three minutes after takeoff from Tehran, killing all 176 on board. Officials denied responsibility for three days, blaming mechanical failure, until satellite evidence and familiesâ€™ pressure forced them to admit the truth.

Despite intimidation, relatives held public vigils and formed the Association of PS752 Victimsâ€™ Families. The tragedy turbocharged public distrust of state narratives and became a key exhibit of deceit and negligence cited in every subsequent protest.

description.en:
On 17 November 2019, Mohsen Mohammadpour was shot dead by security forces during the Aban 2019 protests against fuel price hikes and systemic corruption. He was one of dozens killed in the first days of the uprising, proving the regime would use lethal force without hesitation.

Like other Aban 2019 victims' families, Mohammadpour's relatives continue seeking justice despite threats and intimidation. His memory, alongside other casualties of those protests, forms part of the collective resistance against the Islamic Republic that later inspired movements like Woman, Life, Freedom.

description.en:
On 16 November 2019, Farhad Majd was killed by direct fire from security forces during the Aban 2019 protests. He joined the ranks of victims in the first days when people took to the streets to protest sudden fuel price increases and systemic corruption.

Majd's death, along with dozens of others that same day, showed the Islamic Republic was ready to pay any price to crush economic protests. His family continues seeking justice, and his memory lives on alongside other Aban 2019 victims.

description.en:
On 18 November 2019, Mohammad Mehdi Karami was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Aban 2019 protests. He was one of the victims of the peak days of demonstrations, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters.

Karami's memory, alongside other Aban 2019 casualties, is part of the resistance memory. His family continues seeking justice, and his name is recorded among the victims of those protests.

description.en:
On 20 November 2022, Artin Rahmanian was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. He was one of the young victims of this movement, showing the regime would target even teenagers.

Rahmanian's death, alongside other young casualties of the 2022 protests, fueled public outrage and proved the Islamic Republic was ready to sacrifice anyone to crush the Woman, Life, Freedom movement. His family continues seeking justice.

On 12 November 2022, Arsham Rouhbakhsh was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. He was one of the victims of this movement, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters.

Rouhbakhsh's death, alongside other 2022 protest casualties, is part of the resistance narrative against the Islamic Republic. His family continues seeking justice, and his memory lives on in collective consciousness.

The memory of Amirmohammad Aslani, alongside other Aban 2019 casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of these bloody protests.

description.en:
On 2019-11-16, Ebrahim Ketabdar was killed by direct fire from security forces during the Aban 2019 protests against sudden fuel price hikes and systemic corruption in the Islamic Republic. They were one of dozens of victims of these protests, showing the regime would stop at nothing to crush dissent and was ready to sacrifice anyone who took to the streets.

The memory of Ebrahim Ketabdar, alongside other Aban 2019 casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of these bloody protests.

description.en:
On 2019-11-18, Reza Nazari was killed by direct fire from security forces during the Aban 2019 protests against sudden fuel price hikes and systemic corruption in the Islamic Republic. They were one of dozens of victims of these protests, showing the regime would stop at nothing to crush dissent and was ready to sacrifice anyone who took to the streets.

The memory of Reza Nazari, alongside other Aban 2019 casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of these bloody protests.

description.en:
On 2019-11-16, Omid Azarhoush was killed by direct fire from security forces during the Aban 2019 protests against sudden fuel price hikes and systemic corruption in the Islamic Republic. They were one of dozens of victims of these protests, showing the regime would stop at nothing to crush dissent and was ready to sacrifice anyone who took to the streets.

The memory of Omid Azarhoush, alongside other Aban 2019 casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of these bloody protests.

description.en:
On 2022-10-23, Mohammad Mehdi Karami was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. They were one of the victims of this movement, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters and would even target teenagers and young people.

The memory of Mohammad Mehdi Karami, alongside other 2022 protest casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of this movement.

description.en:
On 2022-11-23, Mohsen Shekari was executed after a hasty trial without access to a chosen lawyer, charged with participating in the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. This rushed execution showed the Islamic Republic uses public executions to terrorize protesters.

The memory of Mohsen Shekari, alongside other 2022 protest executions, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation.

description.en:
On 1996-12-03, Mohammad Mokhtari was assassinated as part of the chain murders carried out by Islamic Republic intelligence operatives. They were one of the prominent intellectuals and writers targeted for their cultural and political activities.

The assassination of Mohammad Mokhtari was part of the policy of physical elimination of dissidents that peaked in 1998-1999. These murders showed the Islamic Republic would stop at nothing to silence opposition voices, and the memory of chain murder victims remains alive in collective consciousness.

description.en:
On 2022-11-24, Saman Yasin was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. They were one of the victims of this movement, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters.

The memory of Saman Yasin, alongside other 2022 protest casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of this movement.

description.en:
On 2022-12-18, Ali Karimi-Nasab was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. They were one of the victims of this movement, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters.

The memory of Ali Karimi-Nasab, alongside other 2022 protest casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of this movement.

description.en:
On 2022-12-21, Arya Rouzbeh was killed by security forces' gunfire during the Woman, Life, Freedom protests. They were one of the victims of this movement, showing the regime would stop at nothing to silence protesters.

The memory of Arya Rouzbeh, alongside other 2022 protest casualties, is recorded in the collective memory of resistance against the Islamic Republic. Their family continues seeking justice despite threats and intimidation, and their name remains on the list of victims of this movement.
